section: This Services Agreement (this "Agreement") is entered into on October 1, 2019 and is made effective as of November 1, 2019 (the "Effective Date"),
explanation: The agreement is dated October 1, 2019, but the effective date is November 1, 2019. This creates ambiguity as to when the agreement is actually in force and could cause confusion regarding the accrual of rights and obligations during this interim period. It is unclear if any actions taken between October 1st and November 1st are covered under the agreement, potentially leading to disputes about services rendered or expenses incurred during this period.

section: This Agreement be deemed effective as of the Effective Date, Agreement and shall terminate on December 31, 2020, unless terminated earlier in accordance with Section 3.2.
explanation: The language 'This Agreement be deemed effective as of the Effective Date, Agreement' is structurally flawed and does not make sense. It appears to be a redundant and grammatically incorrect restatement of the effective date. The intended meaning is likely that the agreement commences on the Effective Date (November 1, 2019) and terminates on December 31, 2020, but the unclear wording creates confusion and could lead to disputes about the agreement's duration.

section: All notices, requests, consents, claims, demands, waivers and other communications hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been given (a) when delivered by hand (with written confirmation of receipt); (b) when received by the addressee if sent by a nationally recognized overnight courier (receipt requested); (c) on the date sent by facsimile or e-mail of a PDF document (with confirmation of transmission) if sent during normal business hours of the recipient, and on the next Business Day if sent after normal business hours of the recipient or (d) on the third day after the date mailed, by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid.
explanation: The notice provision in Section 7 includes conflicting requirements for when a notice is deemed to have been given. Subsections (c) and (d) specify different timing rules for facsimile/email and certified mail, respectively. This is problematic because there is no general rule specifying which method takes precedence if multiple methods are used, creating ambiguity on the valid delivery date.
